awd_abstract_narration:
Cryptographers have invented many different types of encryption. The PIs' research brings many of these under one umbrella, thereby reconceptualizing the landscape of modern cryptography. In the process, the research puts forward some entirely new kinds of encryption. The work is motivated by the needs of existing security practice. Sample questions include how to save space when storing encrypted copies of the same material in the cloud, and how to encrypt a credit-card number by reimagining the process as the shuffling of a deck of cards. The research demonstrates the practical benefits to cryptography and security from inclusive reinterpretations what encryption does.

In more detail, leaky encryption formalizes what it means to divulge some particular function of the message, unifying notions like blockciphers, online ciphers, and order-preserving encryption. Shuffle-based encryption creates blockciphers in a way fundamentally different from the way Feistel and SP networks do. Message-locked encryption can encrypt with a key derived from the message itself, to enable secure  de-duplication. Password-based encryption incorporates a "salt" to provide what the PIs call multi-instance security. Circuit encryption can encrypt a circuit and its input to ciphertexts that permit the evaluation of the one on the other, but in a way that reveals only correctly computed result. These are just some of the aims the research encompasses.

por.por_cntn:
Criminals and governments mount sophisticated attacks to compromise our privacy and security. Encryption is one of the few defenses we have. To be effective, however, we need good encryption methods: they should solve the right problems, we should be able to provide confidence that they do so, and they should be fast enough that we can use them in existing systems. In response, this project creates new forms of encryption and assesses the security of new and old encryption schemes. 

 The project gives attacks to show that the security of some standardized, in-use schemes for Format-Preserving Encryption, widely used to encrypt credit-card numbers, is lower than expected, so that standards need revision. The project provides theoretical foundations, in the form of definitions and proven-secure schemes, for forms of ratcheted encryption, where keys are continually updated to mitigate loss in security from compromise of the device storing the key. The project develops practical ways to use very big keys so as to retain security in the face of malware residing on your system and trying to exfiltrate your key. The project develops encryption schemes that retain security even when the random-number generators they use are buggy or even intentionally subverted. The project studies deterministic encryption as a way to store your information in the cloud in a form that is secure yet permits retrieval by search. The project analyses the security of the GCM encryption scheme used in the ubiquitous TLS protocol that underlies Internet security today.

 The intellectual merit is definitions that formally capture security properties so that we can prove that schemes are secure, and schemes proven to meet these definitions. The broader impact is methods of encryption that resist new, emerging attack vectors and protect the privacy of citizens.
